hints: The layers of gases surrounding the Earth.
Protects us from the sun's radiation.
The air we breathe is in the lowest layer.
All the water on, in, and above the Earth's surface.
Includes oceans, lakes, and glaciers.
It is a crucial component of the water cycle.
The rigid, outermost shell of a rocky planet.
Includes the crust and the uppermost mantle.
Where plate tectonics happen.
The collective name for the solid Earth.
Includes the crust, mantle, and core.
It is the largest of Earth's spheres.
The sum of all living organisms on Earth.
Includes all ecosystems and life forms.
The zone where all life exists.
The outermost solid layer of the Earth.
It is relatively thin compared to other layers.
Can be continental or oceanic.
The thick, rocky layer between the crust and the core.
Makes up most of the Earth's volume.
Where convection currents drive plate movement.
The central and innermost layer of the Earth.
Made mostly of iron and nickel.
Consists of a solid inner part and a liquid outer part.
The theory that the Earth's outer shell is divided into several plates.
Explains earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain formation.
These plates move slowly over the mantle.
A supercontinent that existed during the late Paleozoic and early Mesozoic eras.
It began to break apart about 175 million years ago.
Means 'all land' in Greek.
The preserved remains or traces of ancient organisms.
Help scientists understand the history of life on Earth.
Can be bones, shells, or imprints.
The breaking down of rocks, soil, and minerals.
Can be caused by wind, water, or temperature changes.
A natural process that shapes the Earth's surface.
The process of moving weathered material from one place to another.
Agents include water, wind, and ice.
Can create canyons and valleys.
A large, perennial mass of ice.
Flows slowly over land due to gravity.
Shapes landscapes by carving out valleys.
A mountain or hill with a vent.
Allows magma, ash, and gases to escape from the Earth's interior.
Mount St. Helens is a famous example.
Molten rock located beneath the Earth's surface.
When it erupts, it is called lava.
Found in the mantle and crust.
Molten rock that has erupted onto the Earth's surface.
It cools and solidifies to form new rock.
Seen flowing from a volcano.
A type of rock formed from layers of weathered material.
Includes sandstone and limestone.
Often contains fossils.
A type of rock formed from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava.
Examples include granite and basalt.
Means 'fire-formed'.
A type of rock formed from existing rocks.
Requires heat and pressure to form.
Marble is a good example.
A naturally occurring, inorganic solid.
Has a specific chemical composition and crystal structure.
Quartz, feldspar, and mica are common examples.
A sudden and violent shaking of the ground.
Caused by the movement of tectonic plates.
Measured on the Richter scale.
The scientific study of earthquakes and seismic waves.
Scientists in this field use seismographs.
A major branch of geophysics.
A series of ocean waves caused by large-scale disturbances.
Often caused by an underwater earthquake or volcanic eruption.
Can cause massive devastation to coastal areas.
A fracture or zone of fractures between two blocks of rock.
Where earthquakes often originate.
The San Andreas is a famous one.
The process of ice formation, movement, and retreat.
Occurs during ice ages.
A major force in shaping continents.
The continuous movement of water on, above, and below the surface of the Earth.
Includes evaporation, condensation, and precipitation.
A key process in the hydrosphere.
The process of a liquid changing to a gas.
How water goes from a lake into the atmosphere.
A key part of the water cycle.
The process of a gas changing to a liquid.
Forms clouds in the atmosphere.
A key part of the water cycle.
Water released from clouds in the form of rain, sleet, snow, or hail.
Brings water back to Earth's surface.
A key part of the water cycle.
An underground layer of water-bearing permeable rock.
A source of groundwater.
We can drill wells into this.
Water held underground in the soil or in pores and crevices of rock.
A major source of drinking water.
Recharged by rain and melted snow.
Energy derived from the heat of the Earth's interior.
Used to power some electric plants.
A renewable energy source.
The scientific study of the solid Earth.
Includes the materials it is made of, its history, and the processes that act on it.
The study of rocks.
The scientific study of the atmosphere and weather.
Weather forecasters work in this field.
A branch of atmospheric science.
The scientific study of the oceans and seas.
Includes marine life, currents, and the seafloor.
A branch of Earth science.
The scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena.
Includes stars, planets, and galaxies.
Closely related to Earth science.
The second major layer of the Earth's atmosphere.
Contains the ozone layer.
Jets often fly in this layer.
The lowest layer of the Earth's atmosphere.
Where all weather occurs.
The layer we live in.
The third major layer of the Earth's atmosphere.
Meteors burn up in this layer.
Lies above the stratosphere.
The fourth major layer of the Earth's atmosphere.
Contains the ionosphere.
The hottest layer, but feels cold due to low density.
The outermost layer of the Earth's atmosphere.
Where the atmosphere fades into space.
Satellites orbit here.
A region in the stratosphere.
Absorbs most of the Sun's ultraviolet radiation.
Has been damaged by CFCs.
The warming of Earth's surface and atmosphere.
Caused by gases like carbon dioxide.
Traps heat from the sun.
The long-term average weather patterns in a region.
Not to be confused with weather.
Refers to patterns over decades or centuries.
The state of the atmosphere at a specific time and place.
Includes temperature, humidity, and wind.
Changes from day to day.
A powerful, rotating storm system.
Forms over warm ocean waters.
Has a distinct 'eye' in the center.
A violently rotating column of air.
Extends from a thunderstorm to the ground.
Often forms in 'Tornado Alley'.
The study of Earth as a unified, interconnected system.
Examines the interactions between the four spheres.
A holistic approach to studying Earth.
An elastic wave generated by an impulse like an earthquake.
Travels through the Earth's interior.
P-waves and S-waves are two types.
A measure of the energy released by an earthquake.
Often expressed on the Richter or Moment scales.
A higher number means a more powerful earthquake.
The point on the Earth's surface directly above an earthquake's origin.
Where the shaking is usually strongest.
Determined by seismograph data.
The point within the Earth where an earthquake originates.
Also known as the hypocenter.
Below the epicenter.
A series of ocean waves caused by large-scale disturbances.
Often caused by an underwater earthquake or volcanic eruption.
Can cause massive devastation to coastal areas.
A major area in the basin of the Pacific Ocean.
Where a large number of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur.
About 90% of the world's earthquakes happen here.
The process that occurs at mid-ocean ridges.
New oceanic crust is formed.
Helps prove plate tectonics.
The process where one tectonic plate moves under another.
Results in the formation of trenches and volcanoes.
Occurs at convergent plate boundaries.
The theory that the continents have moved over geologic time.
Proposed by Alfred Wegener.
The precursor to plate tectonics.
A German meteorologist and geophysicist.
Proposed the theory of continental drift.
Died on an expedition in Greenland.
The boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle.
Short for Mohorovicic discontinuity.
Named after a Croatian seismologist.
The movement of heated fluid.
Drives the motion of tectonic plates in the mantle.
Hot material rises, and cold material sinks.
A series of ocean waves caused by large-scale disturbances.
Often caused by an underwater earthquake or volcanic eruption.
Can cause massive devastation to coastal areas.
A type of volcano.
Steep sides and a circular shape.
Formed from explosive eruptions.
A type of volcano.
Also known as a composite volcano.
Forms from alternating layers of lava and ash.
A type of volcano.
Broad, sloping sides.
Formed from effusive lava flows.
An area of volcanic activity away from plate boundaries.
Caused by a rising plume of hot mantle rock.
The Hawaiian Islands were formed this way.
The physics of the Earth and its environment.
Includes the study of seismic waves and the magnetic field.
A branch of Earth science.
The scientific study of the movement, distribution, and management of water.
A branch of Earth science.
Focuses on the hydrosphere.
The scientific study of climate.
Focuses on long-term weather patterns.
A branch of atmospheric science.
The scientific study of glaciers, ice sheets, and ice caps.
A branch of Earth science.
Studies the cryosphere.
The scientific study of fossils and prehistoric life.
Helps reconstruct the history of life on Earth.
A combination of biology and geology.
A system of chronological dating.
Used to describe the timing and relationships of events in Earth's history.
Divided into eons, eras, periods, and epochs.
The largest division of geologic time.
There are four of them: Hadean, Archean, Proterozoic, and Phanerozoic.
Can last for billions of years.
A major division of geologic time.
Examples include the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic.
Smaller than an eon, larger than a period.
A subdivision of a geologic era.
Examples include the Jurassic and Cretaceous.
Smaller than an era, larger than an epoch.
A subdivision of a geologic period.
Examples include the Holocene and Pleistocene.
The smallest division of geologic time.
The period of time before the Cambrian Period.
Covers most of Earth's history.
When the first life forms appeared.
An era of geologic time.
Means 'ancient life'.
When life began to diversify and move onto land.
An era of geologic time.
Means 'middle life'.
The age of the dinosaurs.
An era of geologic time.
Means 'recent life'.
The age of mammals, our current era.
A type of rock formed from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava.
Examples include granite and basalt.
Means 'fire-formed'.
A type of rock formed from layers of weathered material.
Includes sandstone and limestone.
Often contains fossils.
A type of rock formed from existing rocks.
Requires heat and pressure to form.
Marble is a good example.
A common type of igneous rock.
Has large, visible crystals.
Used in countertops and building materials.
A common type of igneous rock.
Forms from rapidly cooling lava.
The most common rock in the oceanic crust.
A common type of sedimentary rock.
Formed from cemented grains of sand.
Often has a layered appearance.
A common type of sedimentary rock.
Mainly composed of calcium carbonate.
Used to make cement and lime.
A common type of metamorphic rock.
Forms from the metamorphosis of limestone.
Used in sculptures and building materials.
A common type of metamorphic rock.
Characterized by distinct bands of minerals.
Forms from high-grade metamorphosis.
A very common mineral.
A key component of granite.
Used in electronics and watches.
A very common mineral.
A key component of granite.
Makes up a large portion of the Earth's crust.
A group of silicate minerals.
Known for their layered structure.
Used in cosmetics and insulation.
The process of forming a solid crystal.
Magma cooling slowly forms large crystals.
A key part of forming igneous rock.
The process by which rocks are bent or broken.
Caused by tectonic forces.
Results in folds and faults.
The process of rock layers being bent into curves.
Caused by compression.
Forms anticlines and synclines.
A fracture or zone of fractures between two blocks of rock.
Where earthquakes often originate.
The San Andreas is a famous one.
A type of fold in rock layers.
A downward-arching fold.
The youngest layers are in the center.
A type of fold in rock layers.
An upward-arching fold.
The oldest layers are in the center.
The process of mountain building.
Caused by tectonic plate collisions.
The formation of the Himalayas is an example.
The state of gravitational equilibrium between the Earth's crust and mantle.
Explains why mountains have deep roots.
The principle of floating crust.
The climate of a region during a past geological epoch.
Studied using ice cores and tree rings.
A field of climatology.
The scientific method of dating based on the analysis of tree rings.
Used to study past climate and environmental conditions.
A very precise dating method.
A cylinder of ice drilled out of a glacier or ice sheet.
Contains a record of past climate.
Used to study past atmospheric composition.
A gas that absorbs and emits radiant energy within the thermal infrared range.
Examples include carbon dioxide and methane.
Contributes to the greenhouse effect.
The biogeochemical cycle by which carbon is exchanged among the four spheres.
Includes photosynthesis and respiration.
A key process in the biosphere.
The measure of the reflectivity of a surface.
Snow has a high one.
The Earth's value is about 0.3.
A fast-flowing, narrow, meandering air current.
Located in the upper atmosphere.
Influences weather patterns.
A climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface waters.
Occurs in the equatorial Pacific Ocean.
Affects weather patterns around the world.
A climate pattern that describes the unusual cooling of surface waters.
Occurs in the equatorial Pacific Ocean.
The opposite of El Nino.
The apparent deflection of moving objects.
Caused by the Earth's rotation.
Influences wind and ocean currents.
A sudden flash of increased brightness on the sun.
Releases a huge amount of energy.
Can disrupt communication systems on Earth.
A natural light display in the sky.
Caused by charged particles from the sun.
Also known as the Northern or Southern Lights.
An astronomical event.
When one celestial body is temporarily obscured.
Can be solar or lunar.
The rise and fall of sea levels.
Caused by the gravitational forces of the Moon and Sun.
Occurs twice a day in most places.
A bowl-shaped depression on the surface of a planet or moon.
Caused by a meteoroid impact or volcanic activity.
Often found on the Moon.
A small rocky body orbiting the Sun.
Found mostly in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter.

A solid piece of debris from an asteroid or comet.
Survives passage through the atmosphere and lands on Earth.
Also known as a 'shooting star'.
An icy small Solar System body.
When close to the Sun, it displays a visible coma and a tail.

A system of stars, stellar remnants, gas, dust, and dark matter.
Held together by gravity.
The Milky Way is our home.
The leading theory for the origin of the universe.

Started from a single point.

The birthplace of stars.

Attracts objects with mass or energy.

A luminous sphere of plasma.
Held together by its own gravity.

A celestial body orbiting a star.

Earth is one.
A natural satellite orbiting a planet.

A system of planets, moons, asteroids, and comets.

A system of stars, stellar remnants, gas, dust, and dark matter.
Held together by gravity.
The Milky Way is our home.
All of space, time, matter, and energy.
Everything that exists.

A major fossil fuel.
Used to generate electricity.
A liquid mixture of hydrocarbons.
Used to produce gasoline, diesel, and plastics.

A naturally occurring hydrocarbon gas mixture.
Mostly methane.
Used for heating homes and cooking.
Energy derived from the heat of the Earth's interior.
Used to power some electric plants.
A renewable energy source.
Energy from the Sun.
Used to generate electricity with panels.
A renewable energy source.
Energy from the movement of air.
Used to turn turbines and generate electricity.
A renewable energy source.
Energy from moving water.
Used in dams to generate electricity.
A renewable energy source.
A fuel derived from living matter.
Examples include ethanol and biodiesel.
A renewable energy source.
The immense period of time occupied by the Earth's existence.
Measured in millions and billions of years.
Helps scientists understand the Earth's history.
The branch of geology concerned with the study of rock layers.

A break in the geologic record.
Represents a period of erosion or non-deposition.
A gap in the rock layers.
A principle of geology.
A rock feature that cuts across another is younger than the feature it cuts.
Helps determine the relative age of rock layers.
The history of life as documented by fossils.
Shows how organisms have changed over time.
Provides evidence for evolution.

A single, large landmass.

Forms from the collision of multiple continents.
An underwater mountain range.
Where new oceanic crust is created.
A key feature of seafloor spreading.

Deposited directly by a glacier.

A lake formed by a block of glacial ice.
The ice melts, leaving a depression.
A feature of glacial landscapes.
Grooves or scratches in rock.
Caused by the movement of glaciers.
Evidence of past glaciation.

We are currently in one.
A period of warmer climate between two glaciations.
The current period we are in.

Connects points of equal temperature.

Located between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

A doughnut-shaped region of icy bodies beyond Neptune.
Home to many dwarf planets and comets.

A theoretical cloud of icy planetesimals.
Surrounds the Sun at a great distance.
The source of long-period comets.
The region around a star where a planet could support liquid water.

A significant environmental problem.

Where freshwater from rivers meets saltwater from the ocean.
A very productive ecosystem.

The process of surface water sinking to the deep ocean.

A series of ocean waves caused by large-scale disturbances.
Often caused by an underwater earthquake or volcanic eruption.

Covered with fine sediment.

The variety of life in the world or in a particular habitat.

Threatened by human activity.
A biological community of interacting organisms.

The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.
Where an organism lives.
A specific place.
The role and position a species has in its environment.
Includes its interactions with other species.
Its 'job' in the ecosystem.
A close and long-term interaction between two different biological species.

A relationship between different organisms.
A type of symbiotic relationship.
Both organisms benefit.
A bee and a flower.
A type of symbiotic relationship.
One organism benefits, the other is unaffected.
Barnacles on a whale.
A type of symbiotic relationship.
One organism benefits at the expense of the other.
A tick on a dog.
A linear network of links in a food web.
Shows who eats whom.
Starts with a producer.
A system of interconnected food chains.
Shows all the feeding relationships in an ecosystem.
More complex than a food chain.
An organism that produces its own food.
Usually a plant or algae.
The base of the food chain.
An organism that feeds on other organisms.
Can be a herbivore, carnivore, or omnivore.
A key part of a food chain.
An organism that breaks down dead organic material.

Recycles nutrients back into the ecosystem.
The scientific study of the relationships between organisms and their environment.
A branch of biology.
The study of ecosystems.
The protection and preservation of natural resources.
A major focus of modern Earth science.
The wise use of resources.
The ability to exist and develop without depleting natural resources.
A key goal of environmental science.
Living in a way that can continue indefinitely.
A resource that can be replenished naturally over time.

A resource that exists in a limited supply.

The opposite of renewable.
A natural phenomenon that can cause loss of life or property.

Caused by gravity, rain, or earthquakes.
A type of mass wasting.

Caused by water erosion of limestone or other soluble rock.

A series of ocean waves caused by large-scale disturbances.
Often caused by an underwater earthquake or volcanic eruption.

A natural disaster.

Spreads quickly in wildlands or rural areas.

A long, narrow corridor of concentrated moisture.
Moves with the weather.
Can cause massive floods.
A large area of low pressure and cold air.
